Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Situation2: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Story:
I stood behind the register, scanning groceries for the handful of customers trickling in. The store was quiet, and I made sure to greet each person with a smile, as expected of me. Suddenly, I noticed Lisa, an acquaintance from my book club, join the line. As I rang up her items, she leaned in and whispered, “Did you hear about Mark? He totally messed up the inventory last week. I don’t know how he still has a job here.”

My mind raced. As an acquaintance, I always tried to avoid gossip or speaking badly about others, but as a cashier, I was supposed to be friendly and make customers feel comfortable. Lisa looked at me, clearly expecting me to agree or at least respond. At the same time, another customer approached, waiting for my attention. I felt a knot tighten in my stomach, torn between the urge to maintain a positive, professional atmosphere and the pressure to engage with Lisa’s comment. My hands hesitated over the register, my smile faltering as I wrestled with what to say next.
